data.title: request: support preserveFocus for vscode.previewHtml
data.body: Feature request: support `preserveFocus` on the `vscode.previewHtml` command. When true, the focus should not change to the preview. This parameter is already supported by `window.showTextDocument` and `OutputChannel.show`.

data.title: [themes] let extensions contribute colors
data.body:
Feature request: provide an interface for the user to customize extension-specific colors/styles.

Specifically:
1. allow an extension to declare various color/styling tag contributions with default values for dark, light, high-contrast, or particular color themes; to look up the current color/style for a tag; and to receive a notification when its color settings change.
2. provide a way for the user to override or specify the colors for any color/style tag. For example:
- via settings.json
- via a color theme that specifies colors/styles for extension-specific tags. (Maybe allow the user to specify a backup theme for tags that the main theme does not specify.)
- provide a UI for the user to customize a color theme, and in particular, allow the user to override select color settings and to specify those that the color theme does not (e.g. extension-specific colors).

Use case: I'm working on an extension that makes heavy use of highlighting. (It is a theorem prover, where lines are highlighted green, blue, red, etc. to indicate what the theorem prover has accepted, rejected, or is still working on. There are ~10 highlights used). I want the colors for the highlights to be user-configurable.

The current solution: an extension can provide configuration settings for the user to specify colors. Problems with this approach:
- coarse grain: it is limited to light vs dark themes
- each extension has to reimplement this approach if they want user-specified colors
- users have to deal with each extension providing a potentially different configuration syntax for a color/style setting.

Colors should not be hard-coded  by an extension. I believe that all extensions using `DecorationRenderOptions` or providing an HTML preview will benefit from a unified way for the user to specify colors.

data.title: Save All doesn't include active document
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T15:27:10.246Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.0.0
- Extensions: Kasik96.format-indent-1.3.0, Telerik.nativescript-0.3.1, dbankier.vscode-instant-markdown-0.1.0, donjayamanne.python-0.5.0, ikappas.phpcs-0.6.1, lonefy.vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter-0.2.1, makao.phpcsfixer-0.0.1, mohsen1.prettify-json-0.0.3, ms-vscode.PowerShell-0.7.2, wwwalkerrun.nativescript-ng2-snippets-1.2.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open up multiple files in the editor and make changes to all of them, but do not save them.
2. Note how all of the files have the dot icon indicating.
3. Select one of the files that are open to make it the "active" file.
4. From the menu, select "Save All"

Expected result: The circle icon is removed from all files since they have all been saved.

Actual result: The circle icon is removed from all files except the active file. It also appears that some code that was stored in the clipboard was automatically pasted in.

Notes: 

As an added means of verification, I've been using the NativeScript livesync feature and noted that all of the changes appear in the synchronized app simulator, except for the active file.

After performing an undo action on the active file, to remove the odd content pasted into the status of the file goes to the "unchanged" status. It could be that the file is actually saving, but then a paste command is erroneously being executed by the app.

I hope this helps. Keep up the great work. I love VS Code!

![vscode_openfiles](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/991466/19655250/3280db24-99d0-11e6-8c68-1dde21b722f3.png)
![vscode_savedfiles](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/991466/19655251/329d9624-99d0-11e6-82d9-2cf1b1e5d9a8.png)

data.title: Dependancies for internal extensions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7
- OS Version: All

Dependancies view does not work well with internal dependancies.  This is actually important as the dependent extension is overridden but does provide interesting context e.g. language ID for activation in the case of `go`.

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Install Go extension
2. Click dependancies
3. Go depends on `vscode.go` (shipped in box)
4. An error is displayed as the view can't resolve it

data.title: Test: verify objects and array previews
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14304:
Complexity: 1
- [x] node: any OS - @sandy081  
- [x] node2: any OS - @weinand 

See #14304 for the details what has changed.

Verify that the previews for objects and arrays in the variables and watches view, and the debug repl are correct and useful.

data.title: Implement preview for objects and arrays in node-debug
data.body:
Currently the `value` attribute of objects and arrays look like this:
- `Object`
- `Array[]`

This makes them rather uninformative if they are not expanded.

With this feature request the variable values in node-debug should be improved in the following way:
- `Object {a: 123, b: "hi", c: true …}`
- `Array(6) [ 1, 2, 3 …]`

To keep previews short:
- only the first 3 properties or array elements are shown,
- the preview covers only the first level of an object or array, so it is not recursive.

data.title: Freezes when Chrome generates userDataDir in workspace
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7 Insider
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. `mkdir test && cd test && git init`
2. Run `chrome --user-data-dir=.vscode/chrome`
3. VSCode freezes, with git activity bar icon showing count 1. When you restart VSCode it's showing count 99+ for all the files Chrome created. Guess the culprit is git watching folder but too many files are created at the same time.

Found this when I was using `"userDataDir": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/chrome"` in Chrome Debugger.

This doesn't seem to repro if I set `userDataDir` to `"${workspaceRoot}/chrome"`, though.

data.title: Test - TS Lint autofix on save
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-tslint/issues/115
- [x] Any platform @jrieken 

Complexity - 2

vscode-tslint is now supporting autofix on save:
- The setting is enabled using `tslint.autoFixOnSave`. Notice that the setting is only honored when `autoSave` is not set to `after delay`.
### Set up
- Side install the latest vscode-tslint
  - `git clone https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-tslint`
  -  `cd vscode-tslint`
  - Run `npm install` on both folders "tslint" and "tslint-server"
  -  In the "tslint" folder run `vsce package`  -> produces tslint-0.5.40.vsix
  - `code-insiders --install-extension  tslint-0.5.40.vsix`
- **Note** that the `tslint` module has a peer dependency on the `typescript`  module, therefore you must install both `tslint` and typescript to enable `vscode-tslint`.
### Test
- Ensure that you have auto save after delay disabled
- Create a typescript file with some [auto fixable warnings](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-tslint/blob/master/tslint/README.md#quick-fixes)

Here is a tslint.json that enables warnings, that are auto fixable.

``` json
{
    "rules": {   
        "quotemark": [true, "double"],
        "no-consecutive-blank-lines": true
    } 
}
```

data.title: Show a prompt when files modified externally on disk (apply, ignore, diff)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Professional.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Load a file into VSCode.
2. Edit the same file in another editor.
3. Look at VSCode and see that file has been updated.

Files modified externally on disk are automatically reloaded without warning. This means that I'm not aware that they have changed. It would good to have an indication that this happened with an choice to compare & merge the new and old files, keep the old version or load the new version. I would guess that this would have to be configurable by file or file type (with a global default). For example, SlickEdit shows a prompt to allow reload, cancel (i.e. keep the file in the editor), close or diff.

data.title: JS - Adopt automatic type acquisition @kieferm
Change HTML grammar to be more precise (embedded modes)
data.body:
Follow up from #14136

Currently, the HTML grammar gives `source.css.embedded.html` also to `<style>` and `</style>`.

The fix is to use `contentName` instead of `name` in the 4 places where HTML embeds other languages.

![bad-ranges](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/19652525/5a1363c8-9a11-11e6-836b-db0284f1c99b.gif)

data.title: "read ECONNRESET" and "unexpected end of file" errors
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T16:21:53.542Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: None

This morning I started getting "read ECONNRESET" and "unexpected end of file" errors in both the stable and insiders versions of vscode. I tried uninstalling both versions and reinstalled just the stable version, and I'm still getting the errors. I also confirmed that I have proper internet connectivity. I also closed the open folder to see if my project was causing it, and still get errors.

Not sure what else to do to troubleshoot this. I'm unable to search for extensions and such.

[EDIT] More error detail:
messageService.ts:128read ECONNRESET: Error: read ECONNRESET
    at exports._errnoException (util.js:1026:11)
    at TLSWrap.onread (net.js:564:26)

workbench.main.js:91 unexpected end of file: Error: unexpected end of file
    at Zlib._handle.onerror (zlib.js:370:17)

data.title: Test extension packs
data.body:
Test for #14277
- [x] Windows @jrieken 
- [x] macOS @aeschli 
- [x] Linux @ramya-rao-a 

Complexity - 4
### Set up
- Make sure you can publish an extension. Ref - http://code.visualstudio.com/docs/tools/vscecli
- Use the [sample test extensions](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/master/extension-deps-sample)
- This repo has 3 extension packs (1, 2, 3) which are already published
- Each has some dependencies - Look at it's package.json for dependencies
- Use these extensions for testing following scenarios (You can also come up with your own if you want to  :) )
- Also do play around with changing dependencies and bumping the versions to test different scenarios for installing and updating.

**Note:** Publishing the extension takes a while to get reflected in the market place.
### Dependencies view
- Search for one of the above extensions and open the editor
- Verify that dependencies tab is show and navigate to it
- Verify that dependencies tree is shown here
- Navigate down the tree to see dependencies of dependencies and verify that they are shown correctly
- If a dependency is a dependency of itself (direct/recursive) then tree stops there.
- If there is an invalid dependency entry, an error entry is shown
- Verify that you can open (also open to side) the dependency by clicking on the name
### UnInstalling packs
- Search for one of the above extensions and install
- Verify that a confirmation is asked if to uninstall the extension only or with dependencies
- Selecting `only` option should uninstall only itself
- Selecting `All` option should uninstall itself and all its dependencies recursively.
- Verify that Uninstall should not uninstall the dependency of the extension if other installed Search for one of the above extensions and open the editor/s depends on this dependency.
- Verify that uninstalling any extension should be prevented if other installed extension/s depends on this.

data.title: Test formatter enablement settings
data.body:
Test for : https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11609
Complexity: 2
- [x] Any OS - @ramya-rao-a 

To disambiguate what formatter VS Code selects when multiple formatter for the same document are available we added the following settings that allow to turn on/off our default formatters: `typescript.format.enable`, `javascript.format.enable`, `json.format.enable`, `html.format.enable`. 

Test that the setting do what thy promise and note that the latter two require a restart for changes to take affect

data.title: Test: Enable / Disable Extensions
data.body:
Test for #2882
- [x] Windows @alexandrudima 
- [x] macOS @bpasero
- [x] Linux @octref 

Complexity - 4
### Open with Workpsace
- Open Extensions View and make sure you have some extensions installed
- Verify that `Disable` action is shown and `Workspace` and `Always` dropdown options are enabled.
- Disable an extension for the workspace
- Reload the window
- Verify that Extension is disabled (not running) only for this workspace. 
- Verify that this extension is running when you open other workspaces
- Verify that Enable action for the extension is shown and also only `Workspace` dropdown option is enabled.
- Enable the extension for the workspace and reload
- Verify that Extension is enabled (running) for the workspace again
- Disable the extension again by selecting `Always` option and reload
- Verify that Extension is disabled (not running) always (any workspace or without workspace)
- Verify that Enable action for the extension is shown and also only `Always` dropdown option is enabled.
- Enable the extension by selecting `Always` option and reload
- Verify that Extension is enabled (running) everywhere
### Open **without** Workspace
- Open Extensions View and make sure you have some extensions installed
- Verify that `Disable` action is shown and only `Always` dropdown option is enabled.
- Disable the extension by selecting `Always` option and reload
- Verify that Extension is disabled (not running) always (any workspace or without workspace)
- Verify that Enable action for the extension is shown and also only `Always` dropdown option is enabled.
- Enable the extension by selecting `Always` option and reload
- Verify that Extension is enabled (running) everywhere
### Enable All / Disable All
- Under the context menu in Extensions View
- Disable All / Disable All (Workspace) should disable all installed extensions always or only for workspace respectively after reload
- Enable All / Enable All (Workspace) should enable all installed extensions always or only for workspace respectively after reload
### CLI
- When VS Code is launched from CLI using the arg `--disable-extensions`
- Verify that Enable / Disable actions are not shown
- Try to play around with all these actions by opening multiple windows.

data.title: Test format document and format selection actions
data.body:
Test for: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13939
Complexity: 2
- [x] Any OS - @alexandrudima 

To make it more discoverable that VS Code has support for format document and format selection we have replaced the 'Format Code' action with 'Format Document' and 'Format Selection'. Test that
- Format Selection only shows in the context menu when there is a selection
- Both actions show only when a corresponding formatter is installed
- Both do what they promise to do

data.title: Autocompletion is losing type information in variable initialization
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10, Build 14393.321

Much to my surprise, any attempt to assign constructor function to a variable doesn't lead to correct autocompletion if that variable used to construct new object.

Example:
![3_cr](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12257359/19645109/d1133e64-99fb-11e6-81e1-1351ab4b1042.png)

What is actually surprising, that doing same operation in object initializer or constructor works:
![4_cr](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12257359/19645525/c6251b56-99fd-11e6-9e61-80d2c5b4ad0d.png)
![5_cr](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12257359/19645522/befb0e26-99fd-11e6-91e9-20f8dba6822d.png)

If if works with object properties, it must work with scope variables as well.
